content: As you can see from the article, I am also critical of Obama’s Syria policy. But you’re overstating the impact of partially damaging one airfield. Countries develop national security strategies in response to many factors. National interest and local conditions matter quite a bit, often more than what the United States does elsewhere. The attack on Shayrat might influence Syria’s behavior — though that isn’t clear — as well as the behavior of other countries involved in the Syrian civil war. But claiming it will transform China’s national strategy is a stretch. Under Obama the U.S. military fired thousands of missiles in seven different countries, killing thousands of people. 59 missiles that (according to the highest estimates) killed fewer than 20 will not, on its own, reorder leaders’ perspectives to the extent you assert.
